title.value: Linking biodiversity, ecosystem function, and Nature’s contributions to people: a macroecological energy flux perspective
title.justification: The title explicitly reflects the main focus of the paper, which is on linking biodiversity, ecosystem function, and Nature's contributions using a macroecological energy flux perspective.
title.quote: Linking biodiversity, ecosystem function, and Nature’s contributions to people: a macroecological energy flux perspective

extractions.description: The paper proposes a framework combining local-scale food web energy flux approaches and large-scale biodiversity models to evaluate ecosystem functions and Nature's contributions to people (NCP) at macroecological scales. This framework aims to upscale ecosystem functions, assess vulnerability of flux-related NCP to climate change, and support multiscale mitigation policies.

type.justification: The paper primarily proposes a theoretical framework rather than conducting empirical research or experiments.
type.quote: Here, we propose a framework that combines local-scale food web energy flux approaches and large-scale biodiversity models to evaluate ecosystem functions and flux-related NCP at extensive spatiotemporal scales.

name.justification: The research focuses on biodiversity, ecosystem functions, and macroecological energy fluxes, aligning it with the field of Ecology.
name.quote: Trends in Ecology & Evolution, May 2024, Vol. 39, No. 5

name.justification: The paper discusses using energy fluxes to evaluate ecosystem functions and Nature’s contributions, which falls under Energy Flux Theory.
name.quote: Food web theory and the distribution of energy fluxes among species can be used to form mechanistic links among perturbations, biodiversity, community structure, and ecosystem functions.

name.justification: Biodiversity models are a key component of the proposed framework to predict ecosystem functions and impacts of NCP.
name.quote: These biodiversity models (referred to here as any model that predicts biodiversity data, such as abundance, interactions, and distribution) can fill in gaps in biodiversity data, providing a comprehensive representation of biodiversity.

name.justification: The paper refers to biodiversity models for predicting species abundance, interactions, and distributions, which are utilized to evaluate ecosystem functions and NCP.
name.quote: These biodiversity models (referred to here as any model that predicts biodiversity data, such as abundance, interactions, and distribution) can fill in gaps in biodiversity data, providing a comprehensive representation of biodiversity.

is_contributed.justification: The paper does not introduce these models as its own contribution but discusses them in the context of the proposed framework.
is_contributed.quote: These biodiversity models can fill in gaps in biodiversity data, providing a comprehensive representation of biodiversity, and their predictive capabilities at regional, continental, and global scales are becoming more precise.

is_executed.justification: The paper discusses the theoretical application of biodiversity models within the framework without mentioning their execution.
is_executed.quote: Three types of biodiversity model are needed to scale up local estimations of ecosystem functions through fluxes: species distribution models, abundance models, and interaction models.

is_compared.justification: There is no mention of numerical comparison between these models in the paper.
is_compared.quote: These models also offer the possibility to integrate future predictions from biodiversity scenarios, enabling forecasting of the future of ecosystem functions and flux-related NCP.

referenced_paper_title.value: Protecting biodiversity (in all its complexity): new models and methods
referenced_paper_title.justification: The paper cites this reference when discussing the capabilities of biodiversity models.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Pollock, L.J. et al. (2020) Protecting biodiversity (in all its complexity): new models and methods. Trends Ecol. Evol. 35, 1119–1128

name.justification: The paper references Fluxweb, an R package for estimating energy fluxes in food webs, emphasizing its relevance to the topics discussed.
name.quote: Fluxweb: an R package to easily estimate energy fluxes in food webs. Methods Ecol. Evol. 10, 270–279

referenced_paper_title.value: Fluxweb: an R package to easily estimate energy fluxes in food webs
referenced_paper_title.justification: The title is cited directly in the paper when Fluxweb is mentioned.
referenced_paper_title.quote: Fluxweb: an R package to easily estimate energy fluxes in food webs. Methods Ecol. Evol. 10, 270–279
